elements.content: In this work, a novel and effective ratio fluorescent porphyrin metal–organic framework (MOF) probe by encapsulating UiO-66­(OH)2 into the porphyrin MOF (PCN-224) was prepared, showing the excellent fluorescence performance in detecting Cu2+. In this probe, the signal from the green-emission UiO-66­(OH)2 encapsulated in PCN-224 was deemed as an effective reference, thus affording an effective built-in correction in complex environmental effects. The red-emission PCN-224 contained the active site for detecting Cu2+. At the same time, Cu2+ can selectively quench the fluorescence intensity of PCN-224. The ratiometric probe therefore gave an effective and reliable Cu2+ determination platform with an LOD value as low as 0.068 nM. This LOD result was better than the Cu2+ concentration limitation in drinking water regulated by World Health Organization (WHO) and reported by some other methods. This provides a simple new sensor for rapidly detecting copper ions, which can be further expanded in various environmental and biological analysis tasks.
elements.clean_text: In this work, a novel and effective ratio fluorescent porphyrin metal-organic framework (MOF) probe by encapsulating UiO-66(OH)2 into the porphyrin MOF (PCN-224) was prepared, showing the excellent fluorescence performance in detecting Cu2+. In this probe, the signal from the green-emission UiO-66(OH)2 encapsulated in PCN-224 was deemed as an effective reference, thus affording an effective built-in correction in complex environmental effects. The red-emission PCN-224 contained the active site for detecting Cu2+. At the same time, Cu2+ can selectively quench the fluorescence intensity of PCN-224. The ratiometric probe therefore gave an effective and reliable Cu2+ determination platform with an LOD value as low as 0.068 nM. This LOD result was better than the Cu2+ concentration limitation in drinking water regulated by World Health Organization (WHO) and reported by some other methods. This provides a simple new sensor for rapidly detecting copper ions, which can be further expanded in various environmental and biological analysis tasks.

elements.content: At present, copper is used in a wide range of applications in many fields, such as renewable energy, building, electrical equipment, and industrial machinery. In addition, copper is a quite important basic element in all creatures including humankind, because it maintains the normal function of organs and life metabolic processes. However, it is harmful for one’s physical health to ingest excessive copper, which leads to diarrhea, vomiting, some stomach upset, and even severe damage in liver and kidney. With the important role of copper in various fields taken into account, there must be excessive amounts of copper coming from industrial waste and domestic sewage in the environment, which could have a bad influence on the surrounding ecosystem and even threaten human health. Copper concentration as stated by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in United States cannot exceed 2 and 1.3 ppm in drinking water, respectively. Therefore, it is very important to provide a simple, rapid, highly sensitive, and specific method for detecting Cu­(II) ions.
elements.clean_text: At present, copper is used in a wide range of applications in many fields, such as renewable energy, building, electrical equipment, and industrial machinery. In addition, copper is a quite important basic element in all creatures including humankind, because it maintains the normal function of organs and life metabolic processes. However, it is harmful for one's physical health to ingest excessive copper, which leads to diarrhea, vomiting, some stomach upset, and even severe damage in liver and kidney. With  the important role of copper in various fields taken into account, there must be excessive amounts of copper coming from industrial waste and domestic sewage in the environment, which could have a bad influence on the surrounding ecosystem and even threaten human health. Copper concentration as stated by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in United States cannot exceed 2 and 1.3 ppm in drinking water, respectively. Therefore, it is very important to provide a simple, rapid, highly sensitive, and specific method for detecting Cu(II) ions.

elements.content: There were various ways to detect copper ion in aqueous solutions, such as some electrochemical methods, inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES), or inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). However, their applications are restricted because these methods are often time-consuming, or require expensive equipment or relatively complex sample preparation. Recently, novel fluorescence detection methods devoted to construction and design of highly effective fluorescence sensors have attracted widespread attention due to its advantages such as simplicity, fast response, high selectivity, and high sensitivity.
elements.clean_text: There were various ways to detect copper ion in aqueous solutions, such as some electrochemical methods, inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES), or inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). However, their applications are restricted because these methods are often time-consuming, or require expensive equipment or relatively complex sample preparation. Recently, novel fluorescence detection methods devoted to construction and design of highly effective fluorescence sensors have attracted widespread attention due to its advantages such as simplicity, fast response, high selectivity, and high sensitivity.

elements.content: In order to meet the design requirements of chemical sensors, novel metal organic framework (MOFs) hybrid materials have attracted widespread interest. MOFs have applications in fields such as gas storage and separation, chemical sensing, catalysis, and biomedicine because of their unique structure. In particular, the rational design of MOFs is very helpful for selectively detecting some small molecules or different ion species through the functionalization of the pore channel surface and the fine-tuning of the chemical environment. Although some research groups have utilized luminescent MOFs to detect Cu­(II), it is also challenging to study how to increase the sensitivity of the MOFs sensor for detecting Cu­(II). In addition, porphyrin and the related macrocyclic compounds as rigid molecules can be used as bridging ligands in the assembly of MOFs due to their adjustable peripheral substituents, large physical size, and additional metallization sites within the ring. Considering that porphyrins are intrinsic components of these MOFs, the introduction of porphyrin can be avoided. Furthermore, self-aggregation of porphyrin can be effectively reduced due to its good separation, which enables a fluorescence response to the analyzed substance. Compared with the porous materials containing porphyrin in their pores, porphyrin serves as an organic ligand for MOFs that are beneficial for stabilization of the framework and to afford accessible, abundant recognition sites. Recent research projects have also confirmed that the porphyrin MOFs are among the materials with the most potential in the field of sensors.
elements.clean_text: In order to meet the design requirements of chemical sensors, novel metal organic framework (MOFs) hybrid materials have attracted widespread interest. MOFs have applications in fields such as gas storage and separation, chemical sensing, catalysis, and biomedicine because of their unique structure. In particular, the rational design of MOFs is very helpful for selectively detecting some small molecules or different ion species through the functionalization of the pore channel surface and the fine-tuning of the chemical environment. Although some research groups have utilized luminescent MOFs to detect Cu(II), it is also challenging to study how to increase the sensitivity of the MOFs sensor for detecting Cu(II). In addition, porphyrin and the related macrocyclic compounds as rigid molecules can be used as bridging ligands in the assembly of MOFs due to their adjustable peripheral substituents, large physical size, and additional metallization sites within the ring. Considering that porphyrins are intrinsic components of these MOFs, the introduction of porphyrin can be avoided. Furthermore, self-aggregation of porphyrin can be effectively reduced due to its good separation, which enables a fluorescence response to the analyzed substance. Compared with the porous materials containing porphyrin in their pores, porphyrin serves as an organic ligand for MOFs that are beneficial for stabilization of the framework and to afford accessible, abundant recognition sites. Recent research projects have also confirmed that the porphyrin MOFs are among the materials with the most potential in the field of sensors.

elements.content: In this work, a chemical sensor of the porphyrin MOFs composite material based on the Cu­(II) ion ratio-based fluorescence shutdown was developed (). This material was prepared by adding prepared UiO-66­(OH)2 (University of Oslo) to the precursor solution of PCN-224 to prepare a composite probe utilizing solvothermal reaction. In the framework of MOFs, the light emitted by the organic ligands of UiO-66­(OH)2 serves as a reference signal. At the same time, the macrocycle containing four N-TCPP units possesses good active sites and can amplify the detection signal. By reacting with Cu­(II) ions, some effect is generated in the porphyrin plane and especially in its electronic structure, resulting in a change in the luminescent properties of the probe, but the luminescence properties of the 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid are not affected. This composite material exhibits high selectivity and convenient sensing properties for many other metal ions on Cu­(II) ions. In addition, low detection limits (LODs) are exhibited by comparison with other MOF sensors. Therefore, the proposed fluorescence sensor based on UiO-66­(OH)2@PCN can be used as a highly effective Cu­(II) ions sensor.
elements.clean_text: In this work, a chemical sensor of the porphyrin MOFs composite material based on the Cu(II) ion ratio-based fluorescence shutdown was developed (). This material was prepared by adding prepared UiO-66(OH)2 (University of Oslo) to the precursor solution of PCN-224 to prepare a composite probe utilizing solvothermal reaction. In the framework of MOFs, the light emitted by the organic ligands of UiO-66(OH)2 serves as a reference signal. At the same time, the macrocycle containing four N-TCPP units possesses good active sites and can amplify the detection signal. By reacting with Cu(II) ions, some effect is generated in the porphyrin plane and especially in its electronic structure, resulting in a change in the luminescent properties of the probe, but the luminescence properties of the 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid are not affected. This composite material exhibits high selectivity and convenient sensing properties for many other metal ions on Cu(II) ions. In addition, low detection limits (LODs) are exhibited by comparison with other MOF sensors. Therefore, the proposed fluorescence sensor based on UiO-66(OH)2@PCN can be used as a highly effective Cu(II) ions sensor.

<title>Process for Encapsulating the UiO-66­(OH)<sub>2</sub> into the Porphyrin

elements.clean_text: 1  Process for Encapsulating the UiO-66(OH)2 into the Porphyrin Metal-Organic Framework (PCN-224) and Concept for Sensing Cu2+

elements.content: Zirconium oxychloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2·8H2O), 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid and benzoic acid were from Aladdin. Pyrrole and methyl p-formylbenzoate were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. Minor modifications from the literature were made to obtain meso-tetra-(4-carbomethoxyphenyl) porphyrin (TCPP-OMe) and also meso-tetra (4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin (TCPP).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Reagents

Zirconium oxychloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2⋅8H2O), 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid and benzoic acid were from Aladdin. Pyrrole and methyl p-formylbenzoate were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. Minor modifications from the literature were made to obtain meso-tetra-(4-carbomethoxyphenyl) porphyrin (TCPP-OMe) and also meso-tetra (4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin (TCPP).

elements.content: 120 mg ZrOCl2·8H2O, 40 mg TCPP, and 1.6 g benzoic acid were dissolved in 8 mL DMF, and then the mixed solution was sonicated for 10 min. After adding 0.8 mg UiO-66­(OH)2 into the solution and sonicating this mixed solution for 20 min, the obtained solution was heated in a muffle furnace at 120 °C for 24 h and then cooled to room temperature. Furthermore, after centrifuging the resulting precipitate with 5000 rpm for 3 min, DMF was used to wash it three times. Then, the solution was centrifuged and finally dried in a vacuum oven.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of UiO-66(OH)2@PCN (probe)

120 mg ZrOCl2⋅8H2O, 40 mg TCPP, and 1.6 g benzoic acid were dissolved in 8 mL DMF, and then the mixed solution was sonicated for 10 min. After adding 0.8 mg UiO-66(OH)2 into the solution and sonicating this mixed solution for 20 min, the obtained solution was heated in a muffle furnace at 120 °C for 24 h and then cooled to room temperature. Furthermore, after centrifuging the resulting precipitate with 5000 rpm for 3 min, DMF was used to wash it three times. Then, the solution was centrifuged and finally dried in a vacuum oven.

elements.content: a and b are the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of UiO-66­(OH)2 and probe, respectively. Their morphologies are shown. UiO-66­(OH)2 has a very homogeneous morphology and a characteristic cubic close-packed special structure having average particle size of 120 nm, which is consistent with the reported results. b shows PCN-224 encapsulated UiO-66­(OH)2. Obviously, the introduction of UiO-66­(OH)2 does not change the PCN morphology. It still maintains a uniform cubic structure with the 1 μm average particle size. In order to further observe the morphological and structural characteristics of the material, and to prove UiO-66­(OH)2 is really wrapped in PCN, the properties of composite materials were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (c). In c, the particles with a uniform size are distributed within the cube, indicating that UiO-66­(OH)2 was successfully wrapped inside PCN-224. At the same time, the morphology of PCN-224 did not change. It is clear that the material was successfully prepared. The elemental analysis of probe in d demonstrates the presence of elemental Zr.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Characterization of Probe

 a and b are the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of UiO-66(OH)2 and probe, respectively. Their morphologies are shown. UiO-66(OH)2 has a very homogeneous morphology and a characteristic cubic close-packed special structure having average particle size of 120 nm, which is consistent with the reported results. b shows PCN-224 encapsulated UiO-66(OH)2. Obviously, the introduction of UiO-66(OH)2 does not change the PCN morphology. It still maintains a uniform cubic structure with the 1 μm average particle size. In order to further observe the morphological and structural characteristics of the material, and to prove UiO-66(OH)2 is really wrapped in PCN, the properties of composite materials were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (c). In c, the particles with a uniform size are distributed within the cube, indicating that UiO-66(OH)2 was successfully wrapped inside PCN-224. At the same time, the morphology of PCN-224 did not change. It is clear that the material was successfully prepared. The elemental analysis of probe in d demonstrates the presence of elemental Zr.

elements.content: SEM images of (a) UiO-66­(OH)2 and (b) probe; (c) TEM image of probe; (d) EDS elemental analysis of probe.
elements.clean_text: 1  SEM images of (a) UiO-66(OH)2 and (b) probe; (c) TEM image of probe; (d) EDS elemental analysis of probe.

elements.content: In order to prove the successful preparation of the material and whether the crystal structure of the MOFs was damaged or changed, PXRD characterization was performed (). For the hydrothermally synthesized UiO-66­(OH)2, the high crystalline and the topologically identical UiO-66 showed the successful preparation of UiO-66­(OH)2. All the main diffraction peaks of PCN-224 at 4.5°, 6.4°, 7.9°, 9.1°, 11.2°, and 13.7° can be observed in the characterization diagram (). These peaks are almost the same as in the previously reported simulated PXRD diagram of PCN-224 crystals. Based on this, the characteristic diffraction peak sites of all the composites show no change by comparison with the standard PXRD. This proves that the UiO-66­(OH)2 structure is not changed after being encapsulated, and the characteristic peaks of PCN-224 still exist after encapsulating the particles.
elements.clean_text: In order to prove the successful preparation of the material and whether the crystal structure of the MOFs was damaged or changed, PXRD characterization was performed (). For the hydrothermally synthesized UiO-66(OH)2, the high crystalline and the topologically identical UiO-66 showed the successful preparation of UiO-66(OH)2. All the main diffraction peaks of PCN-224 at 4.5°, 6.4°, 7.9°, 9.1°, 11.2°, and 13.7° can be observed in the characterization diagram (). These peaks are almost the same as in the previously reported simulated PXRD diagram of PCN-224 crystals. Based on this, the characteristic diffraction peak sites of all the composites show no change by comparison with the standard PXRD. This proves that the UiO-66(OH)2 structure is not changed after being encapsulated, and the characteristic peaks of PCN-224 still exist after encapsulating the particles.

elements.content: PXRD patterns of different materials.
elements.clean_text: 2  PXRD patterns of different materials.

elements.content: Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was used here to further characterize the material. By comparing Figure S-2a with c, UiO-66­(OH)2 was successfully prepared. The broad and scattered absorption peak at 3100–3400 cm–1 is the stretching vibration generating from the associative hydroxyl group. The CO bond and the C−O bond of the ligand have been coordinated with the metal ion to form a complex, which can be indicated by the CO stretching vibration peak of the ligand at 1654 cm–1, the C−O peak at 1491 cm–1, and the shift of the δO=H peak at 1293 cm–1. In Figure S-2d, all characteristic peaks of the probe are present, which proves the existence of UiO-66-(OH)2 and PCN-224.
elements.clean_text: Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was used here to further characterize the material. By comparing Figure S-2a with c, UiO-66(OH)2 was successfully prepared. The broad and scattered absorption peak at 3100-3400 cm-1 is the stretching vibration generating from the associative hydroxyl group. The CO bond and the C-O bond of the ligand have been coordinated with the metal ion to form a complex, which can be indicated by the CO stretching vibration peak of the ligand at 1654 cm-1, the C-O peak at 1491 cm-1, and the shift of the δO=H peak at 1293 cm-1. In Figure S-2d, all characteristic peaks of the probe are present, which proves the existence of UiO-66-(OH)2 and PCN-224.

elements.content: The ultraviolet absorption spectra of the organic ligands 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid and TCPP, UiO-66­(OH)2 and probe are studied (). Through comparative observation, it is found that, after the material composite, the characteristic peaks of UiO-66­(OH)2 are blue-shifted, and the characteristic peaks of PCN are red-shifted. However, the composite materials have their characteristic peaks at the same time, indicating the materials contain UiO-66­(OH)2 and PCN. In addition, the UV–vis spectrum of the probe matches well with the spectrum of TCPP. The porphyrin units in MOFs exist in the form of free-base TCPP, which can be proved by observing whether the four Q bands in the UV–vis spectra are present.
elements.clean_text:
Spectral Characterization of Probe

The ultraviolet absorption spectra of the organic ligands 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid and TCPP, UiO-66(OH)2 and probe are studied (). Through comparative observation, it is found that, after the material composite, the characteristic peaks of UiO-66(OH)2 are blue-shifted, and the characteristic peaks of PCN are red-shifted. However, the composite materials have their characteristic peaks at the same time, indicating the materials contain UiO-66(OH)2 and PCN. In addition, the UV-vis spectrum of the probe matches well with the spectrum of TCPP. The porphyrin units in MOFs exist in the form of free-base TCPP, which can be proved by observing whether the four Q bands in the UV-vis spectra are present.

elements.content: UV–vis spectra of different materials in DMF.
elements.clean_text: 3  UV-vis spectra of different materials in DMF.

elements.content: shows the fluorescence quenching response of the probe at the changed Cu2+concentrations at 25 °C. The probe was dispersed in an ethanol and water (v:v = 1:1) mixed solution, and the excitation wavelength was 415 nm. Using the emission peak of 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid at 531 nm as a reference signal, and the characteristic emission fluorescence of the bulk TCPP as a detection signal, the added Cu2+ responds to its fluorescence change. With the Cu2+ concentration in the solution gradually increasing from 1 μM to 10 μM, the emission intensity of the probe at the strongest TCPP emission peak at 645 nm gradually decreases, but the fluorescence signal of 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid at 531 nm is almost unchanged. Therefore, the emission intensity ratio I 531/I 645 is analyzed as ratio-type detection data. At 10 μM, Cu2+ exhibits a high percentage of fluorescence quenching for the probe, and quenches over 89% of the original fluorescence signal intensity. Stern–Volmer equation shows this quenching efficiency. I I 0 = K s v [ Q ] + 1 where I 0 means the fluorescence signal intensity obtained by the probe before adding the detection target. I means the intensity obtained after adding the detection target. [Q] is actual molar concentration in the detection target solution. K sv is a quenching constant.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Probe

  shows the fluorescence quenching response of the probe at the changed Cu2+concentrations at 25 °C. The probe was dispersed in an ethanol and water (v:v = 1:1) mixed solution, and the excitation wavelength was 415 nm. Using the emission peak of 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid at 531 nm as a reference signal, and the characteristic emission fluorescence of the bulk TCPP as a detection signal, the added Cu2+ responds to its fluorescence change. With the Cu2+ concentration in the solution gradually increasing from 1 μM to 10 μM, the emission intensity of the probe at the strongest TCPP emission peak at 645 nm gradually decreases, but the fluorescence signal of 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid at 531 nm is almost unchanged. Therefore, the emission intensity ratio I 531/I 645 is analyzed as ratio-type detection data. At 10 μM, Cu2+ exhibits a high percentage of fluorescence quenching for the probe, and quenches over 89% of the original fluorescence signal intensity. Stern-Volmer equation shows this quenching efficiency. 1      I     I   0     =   K   s v    [ Q ]  + 1   where I 0 means the fluorescence signal intensity obtained by the probe before adding the detection target. I means the intensity obtained after adding the detection target. [Q] is actual molar concentration in the detection target solution. K sv is a quenching constant.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence emission spectra of probe (50 mg·L–1) with different Cu­(II) ion concentrations from 0 to 10 (λex = 415 nm). (b) Corresponding Stern–Volmer plot of the quenching fluorescence intensity of probe.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Fluorescence emission spectra of probe (50 mg⋅L-1) with different Cu(II) ion concentrations from 0 to 10 (λex = 415 nm). (b) Corresponding Stern-Volmer plot of the quenching fluorescence intensity of probe.

elements.content:
In b, a good linear correlation with R 2 = 0.9947 is shown in 0–10 μM Cu2+. K sv is significant for describing the efficiency of fluorescence quenching. For Cu2+, this constant is 4.03 × 105 M–1.

As shown in b, with the constant increase of Cu2+ concentration, I 531/I 645 decreases continuously, and the linearity is good in the range of 0 to 1 nM Cu2+: the linear relationship at I 531/I 645 is y = 1.478 + 1.004x, R 2 = 0.9996. The fluorescence intensity of the blank probe solution is used to calculate the standard deviation σ before Cu2+ is added (a). Finally, the detection limit of probe for Cu2+ can reach 0.068 nM, which is far below the concentration specified by the WHO and the US EPA in drinking water. This value is also lower than the detection limit of most previously reported MOFs-based Cu­(II) ion sensors, as shown in . It also shows the high sensitivity of the probe for detecting Cu2+ in the aqueous solution.
elements.clean_text:
In b, a good linear correlation with R 2 = 0.9947 is shown in 0-10 μM Cu2+. K sv is significant for describing the efficiency of fluorescence quenching. For Cu2+, this constant is 4.03 × 105 M-1.

As shown in b, with the constant increase of Cu2+ concentration, I 531/I 645 decreases continuously, and the linearity is good in the range of 0 to 1 nM Cu2+: the linear relationship at I 531/I 645 is y = 1.478 + 1.004x, R 2 = 0.9996. The fluorescence intensity of the blank probe solution is used to calculate the standard deviation σ before Cu2+ is added (a). Finally, the detection limit of probe for Cu2+ can reach 0.068 nM, which is far below the concentration specified by the WHO and the US EPA in drinking water. This value is also lower than the detection limit of most previously reported MOFs-based Cu(II) ion sensors, as shown in . It also shows the high sensitivity of the probe for detecting Cu2+ in the aqueous solution.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence spectra of blank probe (50 mg·L–1) at different measurements. (b) Calibration curve of fluorescence intensity against Cu­(II) ion concentration.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Fluorescence spectra of blank probe (50 mg⋅L-1) at different measurements. (b) Calibration curve of fluorescence intensity against Cu(II) ion concentration.

</oasis:table>
</table-wrap>

To investigate the potential of the fluorescent probe for detecting Cu­(II) ions, the fluorescence intensity change of the probe with various cations (Ca2+, Fe3+, Fe2+, Na+, Zn2+, Ag+, Ba2+, Mn2+, Cd2+, K+, and Mg2+) was tested, and the data were analyzed based on the change of I 531/I 645. In , the red bars indicate the effects of various metal ions (20 μM) on the probe, respectively. It is found that only Cu2+ can cause changes in the ratio of fluorescence intensity, while other ions have less influence on the probe. This difference is mainly because that Cu2+ possesses the stronger affinity to the porphyrin core active site in the probe. Then, we further explored the competition experiments between each ion and Cu2+. After the ions reacted respectively with the probe, Cu2+ was added. As shown in , the I 531/I 645 value in each ion solution kept increasing with the addition of Cu2+. Therefore, the probe can be quenched just by Cu2+. This result indicates that the coexistent ions do not interfere with the Cu2+ detection by probe. Therefore, the probe can detect Cu2+ with high selectivity regardless of other ions present or not.
elements.clean_text:
Selectivity and Sensitivity Test of Probe

To investigate the potential of the fluorescent probe for detecting Cu(II) ions, the fluorescence intensity change of the probe with various cations (Ca2+, Fe3+, Fe2+, Na+, Zn2+, Ag+, Ba2+, Mn2+, Cd2+, K+, and Mg2+) was tested, and the data were analyzed based on the change of I 531/I 645. In , the red bars indicate the effects of various metal ions (20 μM) on the probe, respectively. It is found that only Cu2+ can cause changes in the ratio of fluorescence intensity, while other ions have less influence on the probe. This difference is mainly because that Cu2+ possesses the stronger affinity to the porphyrin core active site in the probe. Then, we further explored the competition experiments between each ion and Cu2+. After the ions reacted respectively with the probe, Cu2+ was added. As shown in , the I 531/I 645 value in each ion solution kept increasing with the addition of Cu2+. Therefore, the probe can be quenched just by Cu2+. This result indicates that the coexistent ions do not interfere with the Cu2+ detection by probe. Therefore, the probe can detect Cu2+ with high selectivity regardless of other ions present or not.

elements.content: Fluorescence response of various metal ions and Cu2+ to probe.
elements.clean_text: 6  Fluorescence response of various metal ions and Cu2+ to probe.

elements.content: Fluorescence response of probe in the presence of interfered metal ions in the absence (the black pillar) and presence (the red pillar) of Cu2+.
elements.clean_text: 7  Fluorescence response of probe in the presence of interfered metal ions in the absence (the black pillar) and presence (the red pillar) of Cu2+.

elements.content: For further evaluating the anti-interference ability and the feasibility of using this dual-emission-ratio fluorescent probe for rapid and ultrasensitive detection of Cu2+ in practical applications, the real-time water samples (Yellow River water, tap water) was tested by fluorescence spectroscopy. By adding the different volumes of standard copper solution into 2 mL prepared solutions, the detection results are shown in . In , it is obvious that the proposed method has strong ability to analyze the real samples. Coexisting ions and organic pollutants cannot generate effective interference in the detection, which proves that the probe has excellent selectivity. At the same time, it demonstrates the accuracy and reliability of the probe in detecting Cu2+ in the environmental samples.
elements.clean_text:
Application of the Fluorescent Probes in Real Water Samples

For further evaluating the anti-interference ability and the feasibility of using this dual-emission-ratio fluorescent probe for rapid and ultrasensitive detection of Cu2+ in practical applications, the real-time water samples (Yellow River water, tap water) was tested by fluorescence spectroscopy. By adding the different volumes of standard copper solution into 2 mL prepared solutions, the detection results are shown in . In , it is obvious that the proposed method has strong ability to analyze the real samples. Coexisting ions and organic pollutants cannot generate effective interference in the detection, which proves that the probe has excellent selectivity. At the same time, it demonstrates the accuracy and reliability of the probe in detecting Cu2+ in the environmental samples.

In summary, the luminescence MOFs of porphyrins have been successfully applied to rapidly and specifically detecting Cu­(II) ions. As a novel “turn-off” sensor, the fluorescent probe exhibits excellent fluorescence performance for tracing Cu2+ based on the fluorescence quenching ability of Cu2+ to the probe. This work fully explains that the sensor has sufficient potential to detect Cu2+ of water samples in complex environments, even providing hope for helpfully preventing the copper-related diseases. As discussed, a new simple sensor for rapidly detecting copper ions was successfully developed and can be further expanded in the application of various environmental and biological analysis tasks.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, the luminescence MOFs of porphyrins have been successfully applied to rapidly and specifically detecting Cu(II) ions. As a novel "turn-off" sensor, the fluorescent probe exhibits excellent fluorescence performance for tracing Cu2+ based on the fluorescence quenching ability of Cu2+ to the probe. This work fully explains that the sensor has sufficient potential to detect Cu2+ of water samples in complex environments, even providing hope for helpfully preventing the copper-related diseases. As discussed, a new simple sensor for rapidly detecting copper ions was successfully developed and can be further expanded in the application of various environmental and biological analysis tasks.

cln_elements.content: 120 mg ZrOCl2·8H2O, 40 mg TCPP, and 1.6 g benzoic acid were dissolved in 8 mL DMF, and then the mixed solution was sonicated for 10 min. After adding 0.8 mg UiO-66­(OH)2 into the solution and sonicating this mixed solution for 20 min, the obtained solution was heated in a muffle furnace at 120 °C for 24 h and then cooled to room temperature. Furthermore, after centrifuging the resulting precipitate with 5000 rpm for 3 min, DMF was used to wash it three times. Then, the solution was centrifuged and finally dried in a vacuum oven.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of UiO-66(OH)2@PCN (probe)

120 mg ZrOCl2⋅8H2O, 40 mg TCPP, and 1.6 g benzoic acid were dissolved in 8 mL DMF, and then the mixed solution was sonicated for 10 min. After adding 0.8 mg UiO-66(OH)2 into the solution and sonicating this mixed solution for 20 min, the obtained solution was heated in a muffle furnace at 120 °C for 24 h and then cooled to room temperature. Furthermore, after centrifuging the resulting precipitate with 5000 rpm for 3 min, DMF was used to wash it three times. Then, the solution was centrifuged and finally dried in a vacuum oven.

cln_elements.content:
In this work, a novel and effective ratio fluorescent porphyrin metal–organic framework (MOF) probe by encapsulating UiO-66­(OH)2 into the porphyrin MOF (PCN-224) was prepared, showing the excellent fluorescence performance in detecting Cu2+. In this probe, the signal from the green-emission UiO-66­(OH)2 encapsulated in PCN-224 was deemed as an effective reference, thus affording an effective built-in correction in complex environmental effects. The red-emission PCN-224 contained the active site for detecting Cu2+. At the same time, Cu2+ can selectively quench the fluorescence intensity of PCN-224. The ratiometric probe therefore gave an effective and reliable Cu2+ determination platform with an LOD value as low as 0.068 nM. This LOD result was better than the Cu2+ concentration limitation in drinking water regulated by World Health Organization (WHO) and reported by some other methods. This provides a simple new sensor for rapidly detecting copper ions, which can be further expanded in various environmental and biological analysis tasks.

In b, a good linear correlation with R 2 = 0.9947 is shown in 0–10 μM Cu2+. K sv is significant for describing the efficiency of fluorescence quenching. For Cu2+, this constant is 4.03 × 105 M–1.

As shown in b, with the constant increase of Cu2+ concentration, I 531/I 645 decreases continuously, and the linearity is good in the range of 0 to 1 nM Cu2+: the linear relationship at I 531/I 645 is y = 1.478 + 1.004x, R 2 = 0.9996. The fluorescence intensity of the blank probe solution is used to calculate the standard deviation σ before Cu2+ is added (a). Finally, the detection limit of probe for Cu2+ can reach 0.068 nM, which is far below the concentration specified by the WHO and the US EPA in drinking water. This value is also lower than the detection limit of most previously reported MOFs-based Cu­(II) ion sensors, as shown in . It also shows the high sensitivity of the probe for detecting Cu2+ in the aqueous solution.
cln_elements.clean_text:
In this work, a novel and effective ratio fluorescent porphyrin metal-organic framework (MOF) probe by encapsulating UiO-66(OH)2 into the porphyrin MOF (PCN-224) was prepared, showing the excellent fluorescence performance in detecting Cu2+. In this probe, the signal from the green-emission UiO-66(OH)2 encapsulated in PCN-224 was deemed as an effective reference, thus affording an effective built-in correction in complex environmental effects. The red-emission PCN-224 contained the active site for detecting Cu2+. At the same time, Cu2+ can selectively quench the fluorescence intensity of PCN-224. The ratiometric probe therefore gave an effective and reliable Cu2+ determination platform with an LOD value as low as 0.068 nM. This LOD result was better than the Cu2+ concentration limitation in drinking water regulated by World Health Organization (WHO) and reported by some other methods. This provides a simple new sensor for rapidly detecting copper ions, which can be further expanded in various environmental and biological analysis tasks.

In b, a good linear correlation with R 2 = 0.9947 is shown in 0-10 μM Cu2+. K sv is significant for describing the efficiency of fluorescence quenching. For Cu2+, this constant is 4.03 × 105 M-1.

As shown in b, with the constant increase of Cu2+ concentration, I 531/I 645 decreases continuously, and the linearity is good in the range of 0 to 1 nM Cu2+: the linear relationship at I 531/I 645 is y = 1.478 + 1.004x, R 2 = 0.9996. The fluorescence intensity of the blank probe solution is used to calculate the standard deviation σ before Cu2+ is added (a). Finally, the detection limit of probe for Cu2+ can reach 0.068 nM, which is far below the concentration specified by the WHO and the US EPA in drinking water. This value is also lower than the detection limit of most previously reported MOFs-based Cu(II) ion sensors, as shown in . It also shows the high sensitivity of the probe for detecting Cu2+ in the aqueous solution.
